name: Ethiopia
currentCrisisSummary:
Ethiopia faces multiple humanitarian catastrophes stemming from the **violent breakdown** of its **ethnic federalist political system** and the unresolved legacies of its **internal imperial formation**. The country reels from the devastating 2020-2022 Tigray war while confronting large-scale armed conflicts between the federal government and regional forces in Amhara and Oromia.

These conflicts represent a catastrophic failure to resolve political questions rooted in historical grievances. Instead, **brutal military force** has resulted in mass displacement, atrocities, service collapse, and acute food insecurity. This is not merely ethnic strife but a **deep structural crisis of the Ethiopian state**, exacerbated by **external geopolitical interests** vying for influence.

imperialRoot.imperialPower: Ethiopian Empire (late 19th c. - 1974), Italy (1936-1941), US & USSR (Cold War)
imperialRoot.legacy:
The modern Ethiopian state formed through **internal imperial expansion**. The Amhara-dominated centre conquered southern peoples, creating a multi-ethnic *prison of nations*. Grievances from this **violent state formation** (land, language, subjugation) are the root of today's conflicts.

This was layered with external pressures: Italian **colonial occupation** and **Cold War patronage**. The US-backed monarchy and Soviet-backed Derg regime used **foreign military aid** to suppress dissent, militarising the state.

historicalContext.title: Ethnic Federalism and TPLF Hegemony
historicalContext.description: The 1995 constitution established **ethnic federalism** to resolve the 'national question'. In practice, this system was captured by the **Tigray People's Liberation Front (TPLF)**, which (from 1991-2018) established an **authoritarian hegemony**, with a **minority ethnic elite** dominating the state's entire political, security, and economic apparatus. Abiy Ahmed's 2018 rise was a direct result of mass (Amhara/Oromo) protests against this system. His subsequent **centralising reforms** violently shattered this entrenched order, leading to the 2020 Tigray War.

historicalContext.title: From Developmental State to Neoliberal Shock Therapy
historicalContext.description: Long a *developmental state* reliant on **foreign aid**, Ethiopia since 2018 underwent a rapid **neoliberal transition** (**privatisation**, **deregulation**, attracting **foreign capital**). This **economic 'shock therapy'** is also a political project. The resulting struggle over economic resources drives the current civil wars.

historicalContext.title: The Post-Tigray Betrayal: Amhara & Oromia Conflicts
historicalContext.description: The current wars stem from the fallout of the Tigray conflict. The federal government's 2023 decision to **forcibly dismantle regional special forces** was seen as a profound **betrayal** by the Amhara Fano militia, who had been federal allies. This, combined with the perception that the Pretoria peace deal ignored their land claims (Welkait), triggered a new, large-scale war. This conflict runs in parallel to the long-running insurgency in Oromia.

historicalContext.title: Land Grabs and Rural Dispossession
historicalContext.description: Ethiopia experiences widespread **land grabs**. Under both state models, fertile land has been leased to **foreign corporations** for agribusiness, often involving **violent dispossession** of local communities. This modern **resource extraction** fuels resentment against the central state.

historicalContext.title: Geopolitics of the Horn and Proxy Interests
historicalContext.description: Ethiopia is a focal point of **geopolitical competition**. **External actors** (Eritrea, UAE, Turkey, US, China) pursue strategic interests. **Foreign drones** (UAE) were decisive in Tigray and fuel ongoing conflicts. These **interventions** provide tools for war, prioritising external goals over peace.

historicalContext.title: International Law and Accountability
historicalContext.description: **Accountability** for war crimes and crimes against humanity committed during the Tigray conflict and in other regions remains elusive. Despite documentation by UN bodies and human rights organisations, **impunity** prevails due to geopolitical considerations. **International legal mechanisms** face political obstruction, preventing justice for civilians subjected to **systematic sexual violence**, **starvation as a weapon of war**, and **indiscriminate attacks on civilians and infrastructure**. The **African Union** and **UN** processes have been inadequate, lacking teeth to enforce compliance.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: Hundreds of thousands killed (est. 300k-600k in Tigray alone) directly by fighting or indirectly through **conflict-induced starvation and healthcare collapse.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 20 million require aid due to the devastating convergence of **internal war, state fragility, drought, and economic instability.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Food Insecurity
humanitarianImpact.description: An estimated 15.8 million face crisis-level hunger due to **warfare destroying harvests and livelihoods.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 3.5 million internally displaced by **state/non-state violence** and **climate shocks**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugees
humanitarianImpact.description: Hosts nearly 1M refugees, while hundreds of thousands of Ethiopians fled abroad due to **political violence**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Sexual Violence as Weapon
humanitarianImpact.description: Systematic sexual violence used by all sides (esp. Tigray) as a **deliberate tactic of war**.

timeline.event: **Imperial Expansion**: Emperor Menelik II doubles the size of the Ethiopian empire, conquering and incorporating diverse peoples in the south. This violent process of internal colonisation creates the *prison of nations* and the historical grievances over land and autonomy that define modern Ethiopian politics.
**End of the Monarchy**: Emperor Haile Selassie is overthrown by the Derg, a Marxist-Leninist military junta backed by the Soviet Union, which intensifies repression.

**The 'Red Terror'**: The Derg regime unleashes a campaign of violent political repression against its opponents, killing tens of thousands. The brutality of the state radicalises many ethno-nationalist movements, including the TPLF, cementing armed struggle as the only viable path to power.

**Fall of the Derg**: A coalition of rebel groups, the EPRDF, overthrows the Derg regime. The coalition is immediately dominated by its architects, the **TPLF**, who establish a 27-year political and economic hegemony.
**Ethnic Federalism Established**: A new constitution is adopted, restructuring Ethiopia as a federation of ethnic-based regions, in practice dominated by the TPLF.

**Ethiopia-Eritrea War**: A brutal, conventional border war erupts between the two former allies, resulting in immense casualties. The conflict entrenches deep animosity between the TPLF-led government in Ethiopia and the Eritrean state, a key factor in Eritrea's intervention in the 2020 Tigray War.
**New Leadership**: Following years of protests, Abiy Ahmed becomes Prime Minister, initially promising democratic reforms but soon pursuing a centralising agenda that dismantles the TPLF-led order.
**Tigray War**: A brutal war breaks out between the federal government and the TPLF. The conflict involves Eritrean and Amhara regional forces and leads to a catastrophic humanitarian crisis.
**Pretoria Peace Agreement**: A peace deal is signed, formally ending the war in Tigray, but its implementation remains fraught with challenges.

**New Wars Erupt**: The federal government's decision to **dismantle regional special forces** is seen as a betrayal by their former allies, the Amhara Fano. A new, large-scale war erupts in Amhara, running parallel to the intensifying conflict against the OLA in Oromia.

The primary national humanitarian organisation, providing emergency response, ambulance services, and assistance to vulnerable communities.

advocacy.title: Support Political Solutions
advocacy.description: Demand an end to military operations and support inclusive, negotiated political solutions to the conflicts in Amhara, Oromia, and other regions.

advocacy.title: Demand Accountability for War Crimes
advocacy.description: Call for independent investigations and accountability for war crimes and crimes against humanity committed by all parties in the Tigray war.

advocacy.title: Implement Peace & Allow Aid Access
advocacy.description: Advocate for the full implementation of the Pretoria Peace Agreement and ensure unfettered humanitarian access to all conflict zones.

advocacy.title: Oppose Arms Sales
advocacy.description: Oppose the sale of arms and military technology, including armed drones, to the Ethiopian government and other armed actors in the region.

advocacy.title: Amplify Local Voices
advocacy.description: Amplify the voices of Ethiopian human rights defenders, journalists, and civil society organisations working for peace and justice.

reading.title: *A History of Modern Ethiopia, 1855-1991*
reading.description: Bahru Zewde details the creation of the modern Ethiopian empire-state, providing essential context for the historical grievances underpinning today's conflicts.

reading.title: *The Real Politics of the Horn of Africa: Money, War and the Business of Power*
reading.description: Alex de Waal provides a critical analysis of how the political economies of the region, based on a market for political loyalty and violence, drive conflict.
